subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] get your news in QS!
msgSnippet: ... Yes, using a proxy server sounds like a good idea. It involves more sophisticated code than what I have, but over time perhaps others could develop this. I
messageBody:
oliver langan wrote:
>
>
> This really cool, Paul. You definitely get geek points, and it will be
> very helpful for reading practice.
>
>
> I also missed the namer dots, can those in some cases be added to the
> dictionary? Certainly Pakistan is only ever a name (though I guess
> pakistani would not be). That word totally threw me, by the way, since
> I pronounce it as "pea ah key eat see tea ah no," perhaps from watching
> the BBC.
>
> I think the ideal implementation of this would be as a translating proxy
> server. (I have some experience working with these). For each web
> request, you fetch the page, do some complicated stuff to only select
> the text on the page (no HTML/script/CSS), and translate the text on the
> fly. However, that is really only going to work with the Unicode font:
> the browser should default to it as the only available typeface with the
> correct characters, even though the page would be designed to use other
> fonts.
>
> (And what works for HTML pages will also work for RSS.)
>
> Of course, it is much easier to think of a solution than to implement
> it. But I'd love to check out the code... just not this upcoming crazy
> week :)
>

Yes, using a proxy server sounds like a good idea. It involves more
sophisticated code than what I have, but over time perhaps others could
develop this. I know with an HTML parser, you can separate the text from
the tags, keep the tags the same, and transliterate the text. Right now
the flavor of the news might not suit everyone's tastes.

Paul
